perturbation.original_text: AT&T shall pay Vendor no later than sixty (60) days after receipt of such monthly payment request for Structured Payments. AT&T shall pay, or provide a written notice of any good faith dispute to, Vendor no later than ninety (90) days after receipt of an invoice for Maintenance Fees. Any dispute of an invoice for Maintenance Fees shall be made by AT&T in good faith and shall set forth in writing a detailed description of the disputed amounts and the reason for such dispute. Notwithstanding any good faith dispute, AT&T shall pay all undisputed amounts in full to Vendor no later than the due date for such invoice. Invoices received by AT&T more than one (1) year after the Delivery of Material and Deliverables or the provision of Services are untimely and AT&T has no obligation to pay such invoices.
perturbation.changed_text: AT&T shall pay Vendor no later than ninety (90) days after receipt of such monthly payment request for Structured Payments. AT&T shall pay, or provide a written notice of any good faith dispute to, Vendor no later than one hundred and twenty (120) days after receipt of an invoice for Maintenance Fees. Any dispute of an invoice for Maintenance Fees needs not be made by AT&T in good faith nor setting forth in writing a detailed description of the disputed amounts. Notwithstanding any dispute, AT&T shall pay all amounts in full to Vendor at AT&T's discretion. Invoices received by AT&T more than two (2) years after the Delivery of Material and Deliverables or the provision of Services are untimely and AT&T has no obligation to pay such invoices.
perturbation.explanation: The original text requires payments be made within 60 or 90 days. The modified text increases this to 90 and 120 days respectively. Additionally, it removes the requirement for 'good faith' disputes and allows payment at AT&T's discretion. Finally, it modifies the period after which invoices are considered untimely from one year to two years, potentially conflicting with state Prompt Payment laws.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Prompt Payment laws in various states (e.g., California Business and Professions Code ยง 7159.5) mandate specific payment deadlines for contractors and subcontractors, often shorter than 90 or 120 days. Removing the 'good faith' requirement violates the implied duty of good faith and fair dealing in contract law.

perturbation.original_text: The warranty period for all Material (excluding AT&T Provided Equipment) shall commence upon Delivery of such Material to Vendor from the OEM and shall continue for a period equal to the longer of (i) [***] or (ii) the applicable warranty period actually received by Vendor from the OEM for such Material Vendor acquired directly from the OEM, including the Vendor Provided Equipment as defined in the Build Addendum (the "Material Warranty Period"). Vendor provides no warranty for Material with respect to any AT&T Provided Equipment. The warranty period for workmanship and all Services provided hereunder, including the Build Services contemplated in the Build Addendum, shall commence upon Location Acceptance of the applicable Cell Site and continue for a period equal to [***] from Location Acceptance of the applicable Cell Site (the "Workmanship Warranty Period").
perturbation.changed_text: The warranty period for all Material (excluding AT&T Provided Equipment) shall commence upon Delivery of such Material to Vendor from the OEM and shall continue for a period equal to thirty (30) days or (ii) the applicable warranty period actually received by Vendor from the OEM for such Material Vendor acquired directly from the OEM, including the Vendor Provided Equipment as defined in the Build Addendum (the "Material Warranty Period"). Vendor provides no warranty for Material with respect to any AT&T Provided Equipment. The warranty period for workmanship and all Services provided hereunder, including the Build Services contemplated in the Build Addendum, shall commence upon Location Acceptance of the applicable Cell Site and continue for a period equal to thirty (30) days from Location Acceptance of the applicable Cell Site (the "Workmanship Warranty Period").
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the warranty period to 30 days could be seen as unconscionable depending on the type of material and service provided. It shifts a disproportionate amount of risk onto AT&T, especially if the typical lifespan or reasonable expectation of the materials and workmanship far exceeds 30 days.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Uniform Commercial Code (UCC) - Specifically, implied warranties of merchantability (UCC ยง 2-314) and fitness for a particular purpose (UCC ยง 2-315). A 30-day warranty may be deemed insufficient if it fails to provide a reasonable period for latent defects to manifest.

perturbation.changed_text: (b) Vendor will pay any penalty, interest, additional tax, or other charge that may be levied or assessed as a result of the delay or failure of Vendor, for any reason, even if AT&T did not fully provide Vendor such amounts or other information, to pay any tax or file any return or information required by law, rule, or regulation or by this Agreement to be paid or filed by Vendor.
perturbation.explanation: By forcing the vendor to pay any penalty, interest, additional tax, or other charge regardless of fault, it violates fundamental principles of fairness and due process.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Breach of contract, violation of fundamental fairness, and violation of agency duties.
